title: 115_hr2493
content: The Act may be cited as the "Conflicts from Political Fundraising Act of 2017". Congress finds that public confidence in the Federal Government relies on officers and employees avoiding conflicts of interest. The risk arises when nominees or appointees have ties to political entities. Since the Citizens United decision in 2010, corporate spending under Federal laws has increased. Since the Citizens United decision in 2010, corporate political spending under Federal laws has significantly increased. Contributions to entities organized under section 501(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 can be made anonymously, raising concerns about conflicts of interest. Current financial disclosure requirements do not mandate reporting donations to political action committees or certain entities, leading to potential conflicts of interest. Entities organized under section 501(c)(4) or section 501(c)(6) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 should disclose conflicts of interest to the Office of Government Ethics for resolution through ethics agreements. SEC. 3. DISCLOSURE OF CERTAIN TYPES OF CONTRIBUTIONS. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of a "covered contribution" under the Ethics in Government Act of 1978, specifying it as a payment or deposit of money made by or on behalf of a covered individual to a political organization. The curr_chunk specifies that a covered contribution is made to a political organization or an organization described in certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code that promotes or opposes changes in Federal laws or regulations. The curr_chunk prohibits covered individuals from making contributions to political organizations that promote or oppose changes in Federal laws or regulations. The curr_chunk outlines restrictions on covered individuals making contributions to political organizations subject to Federal laws or regulations. The curr_chunk specifies that contributions must be made to tax-exempt organizations described in specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code, with a minimum amount required for the calendar year. The curr_chunk defines a 'covered individual' as someone nominated or appointed to a 'covered position', which includes specific positions in the federal government. The curr_chunk specifies positions that qualify as 'covered positions' for a 'covered individual', including roles in the Executive Schedule, Senior Executive Service, and schedule C of the Code of Federal Regulations. The curr_chunk amends the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 to include disclosure requirements for covered positions, with specific details on filing reports for individuals assuming such positions. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 now includes disclosure requirements for covered positions, with details on filing reports for individuals assuming such positions within 30 days. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 mandates disclosure requirements for covered positions, including filing reports within 30 days of assuming such positions. The term 'applicable period' refers to the year of filing and the 4 calendar years preceding it for reports filed under subsections (a) or (b) of section 101, and the preceding calendar year for reports filed under subsections (d) or (e) of section 101. A 'covered gift' is a gift made to a covered individual, their spouse, or dependent child, by an entity described in section 109(2)(A)(i)(II), and would have been required to be reported under subsection (a)(2). The report filed by a covered individual must include details of each covered contribution, such as the date, value, and the person making the contribution. A covered contribution solicited must include details like value, name of contributor, and recipient. Contributions made by or on behalf of a covered individual may pose a conflict of interest, but exemptions can be granted by the Director of the Office of Government Ethics. The covered contribution exemption does not harm Government integrity or public confidence. Reports by covered individuals must include gift information. The Director of the Office of Government Ethics must provide reports and ethics agreements to Congress upon request. The Director of the Office of Government Ethics must provide reports and ethics agreements to Congress for covered individuals nominated or serving in covered positions. Rules on ethics agreements will be issued promptly for agencies in the executive branch. Technical and conforming amendments will be made to the Ethics in Government Act of 1978. Amendments were made to sections 101(f) and 103(l) of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978, updating references to different sections within the Act.
